newsitem.title: ANGOLA: U.N. commanders says Angolan diamond area tense.
newsitem.headline: U.N. commanders says Angolan diamond area tense.

text.p: The United Nations said on Tuesday a fact-finding mission to Angola's northeastern diamond area, where fighting has been reported between the government army and former rebel UNITA, had found the area tense.
The mission, led by the U.N. force commander in Angola Philip Sibanda of Zimbabwe, also found a large number of internally displaced people and heard sporadic artillery fire, a U.N. statement said.
It said the delegation visited the town of Luia and a crossing point on the Cassai River which marks the eastern border between Angola and the Democratic Republic of Congo, formerly Zaire.

Sibanda was accompanied by military observers from Portugal, Russia and the United States who are helping the U.N. oversee a two-year-old peace process signed by the government and UNITA in 1994 to end two decades of civil war.

"The situation in Luia, Lunda Norte, remains tense. General Sibanda said he could hear sporadic artillery fire in the distance during his visit. He also observed a large number of internally displaced people," the statement from the U.N. spokesman's office in Angola said.
The statement also said the delegation had been "manhandled on their arrival by UNITA militants".
"UNITA's personnel were angry that media reports are claiming that a UNAVEM statement issued on Saturday...said there is no conflict in the Lundas," the statement said.
Sibanda visited three towns in the northeast last Friday, where clashes between the two Angolan factions were reported two weeks earlier.
In a statement after that visit, Sibanda said he had found the situation calm with no signs of heavy combat.
"UNAVEM is well aware that the Lundas have long been an area of tensions between the government and UNITA," Tuesday's statement said.
It added that the U.N. was investigating reports of heavy fighting in the northeast and its findings would be presented to a joint peace commission later this week.
Expatriate mining officials on the ground in the area of the fighting told Reuters of gunbattles between both sides south of the town of Nzage two weeks ago.
The reports were independently confirmed with senior military sources who asked not to be named.
They said the government, while moving south, had come across strong resistance from armed groups in the area controlled by UNITA.

These sources had also witnessed the government reinforcing its artillery stocks last Monday, and said state forces appeared determined to continue their advance south deeper into UNITA's diamond areas.
Although the government and UNITA were joined in a unity government in April, the former rebels still hold onto some 80 percent of all diamond territory in the country, mostly in the northeast.
In terms of the 1994 peace treaty, the government can now extend state administration into UNITA areas after the movement last year declared its guerrilla army had been dismantled and disarmed.
But UNITA has accused the government of forcibly taking territory.

An Angolan government military build-up in the northeast began during a seven-month war in Angola's northern neighbour of Zaire aimed at protecting the country's borders after government ministers claimed thousands of refugees from the former Zaire had crossed the border.
But Western diplomats say this was a pretext to retake diamond territory from UNITA.
